headline: London Broil
description: This London broil recipe is a quick fix for an inexpensive cut. Mix up a flavorful marinade and let the meat sit overnight for a perfect flank steak.

video.description: See how to make a flavorful marinade for an amazing grilled London Broil.
video.name: London Broil II

name: London Broil

recipeInstructions.text: Mix soy sauce, ketchup, vegetable oil, garlic, salt, pepper, and oregano together in a small bowl.

Score both sides of steak in a diamond cut, about 1/8 inch deep. Rub marinade into both sides of the meat. Store in a covered dish or resealable plastic bag in the refrigerator to marinate for 5 to 6 hours, or overnight. Flip meat every few hours.
Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat, and lightly oil the grate.
Place steak on the preheated grill. Cook for 3 to 7 minutes per side, or to the desired doneness.

review.reviewBody: This isn't your mother's shoe-leather London Broil done in a pan of water in the oven like my mother used to make when I was a kid! I used to despise eating any meat or roast she would make as it was always so dry and tough. I vowed to never put my family through that ordeal and learned how to cook. I was skeptical about this recipe since the marinade is/was so simple. I am used to adding tons of spices, wine, etc., and rarely stick with a recipe. BUT... this easy-peasy recipe caught my eye. My London Broil turned out phenomenal! I ended up marinating it for 24 hours as I just wasn't able to get back to making it within 5 hours. During that 24 hours of marinating though I did flip it and rubbed it down each time (about 4 times in all). I thought I'd try making it in a skillet on the stovetop. I used very high heat since I have an electric stove (blah). I did the recommended time of 5 minutes per side. It was perfecto! This was a really good deal for just $12 bucks (fed 4) and was a decent quality of meat from my local grocer which is known for the quality of their meats. I will be making this more often.
Tasted good good good good

You must cut the meat very thin. Mine was marinated for 24 hours but was not tender. I will try marinating for 2 days next time. I might try the hammer method too. Also, I added lemon juice to help with tenderizing. It was a thick piece of london broil.
Instead of soy sauce I used 2.5-3 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce & 3 cloves of garlic. Also added Montreal steak seasoning

It was good. I like it rare so I only grilled it for 3 minutes on both sides, and let it rest for 10 minutes. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because it didn't like the oregano, and I normally love oregano, but it just didn't work in the dish for me. I will make this marinade again but omit the oregano.
This recipe was fabulous! First time I used the marinade and it was perfect. This will be my go to marinade going forward. Absolutely the best

My family RAVED over this! Everyone had seconds, and my husband said he liked this more than steak. I was leery about the ketchup, but it thickened the consistency and helped keep the meat moist and tender. The only thing I changed was to leave out the salt, I thought it would be too much on top of the soy salt.
Made the steak so tender it melts in your mouth! This will be our staple for bbq season!

Excellent recipe. It was a bit on the thick side, so I seared it on both sides, then let it finish offset from the grill burner at slightly lower heat. Cooked to medium well and thin sliced it. It is now on my BBQ menu list.
Great marinade! I almost ate the steak raw, it smelled so good. I will definitely use this simple marinade again. I did add an extra clove of garlic.

Really awesome. We grilled ours much longer than time stated, hoever. We took it off the grill after 5 minutes a side and it was not quite cooked all the way and very chewy. Put it back on again, and it was perfection.

New go to marinade for London Broil! I used pepper plant hot sauce in lieu of ketchup and garlic olive oil in lieu of vegetable oil. I did score the meat and also let it marinade for a day. Super flavorful, don’t overcook this cut as it is “chewy” when more we’ll done. Rare/med rare is perfect!
Made this twice, once with London broil (top round) on the grill and once with boneless NY strip in a cast iron pan. Fabulous. Will make again and again.
Family loved it. Reduced pepper to 1/4 tsp as we are not super spicy lovers. Have made several times.

I made this twice...the first time I followed the recipe exactly as presented and grilled it on my Pit Boss pellet grill using hickory pellets...yummmmm. The next time I made London broil I slightly modified the marinade by adding 1 tbs of red wine vinegar, substituting barbecue sauce for the catsup, and marinated the meat in a sealable freezer bag, adding about 1/2 cup of sliced raw onion. Cooked it the same way and O M G, what a difference! The meat was noticeably more tender and the flavor of the marinade was simply outstanding. Served it with seasoned roasted baby red potatoes and cole slaw and grilled corn on the cob...This is a new family favorite!
Love this marinade! I usually buy a family pack of London Broil when its on sale and freeze the second one in the marinade for "emergencies!"

The seasoning, with some lemon juice added (and worcestershire if that is not called for) was amazing. However, the london broil was sooo tough it was inedible. Keep the seasoning, dump the london broil, or cook it in a crock pot after marinating overnight.

I was thoroughly impressed. Skepticism, at first, about the soy sauce and ketchup, but I kept going! I used cloves of garlic, replace vegetable oil with EVOO, and added lime juice. This will be added to my favs list.
really good marinade! We have also used it for pork steaks and other grilled beef cuts.
Delish!
Delicious! Moist and chewy
I will use this marinade again. The flavor is very good.

Oh my gosh wonderful! Loved the marinade, cooked perfectly on the grill and will definitely make it again! Some changes I made: didn’t have oregano, sprinkled with McCormick’s Grill seasoning, marinated 2 days in a covered glass dish. My girlfriend also made this dish and she put it in the marinade then froze it for two days.
Great recipe everyone loved it. One suggestion for everyone is to tenderize the cut before marinading it. This makes the meat so tender and makes you think that you bought an expensive cut.
Used this with a london broil cut of meat, did not have oregano on hand so added a little italian seasoning - marinated a little over 24 hours and this was delicious! will make again!
Super, super good! I cooked it in a crockpot on low all day . turned out perfectly!
I made this with London Broil. It was tasty. Marinated for one day.
I made this with London Broil. It was tasty. Marinated for one day.
Delish just as it is! Came out amazing!
Turned out pretty good. Get the grill screaming hot for good grill marks
This is the only way I make London broil now. I've become famous for it in my family -- it's my most requested summertime meal! Don't change a thing -- it's perfect.
I added a little onion powder and a little extra catch-up. It was absolutely delicious! I cook the meat into thin slices and/grilled them. I serve them with grilled peppers and onions

I bought a London broil because it was on sale. I followed the instructions to a "T" and it was wonderful! I cooked it on my preheated gas grill on high heat for 6 minutes on the one side and 5 minutes on the other side, then left it rest under a foil tent for about ten minutes. The outside edges were medium, but the main part was a perfect rare. My husband and I really enjoyed it. I have enough left over to make sandwiches for our lunches. I will definitely be making it again.

Really amazing! Best part is I realized at soIdid do the whole tenderizing it with poking holes and meat tenderizer with water the day before I marinated But the I’ve done this a few times now and add some lemon juice as others suggested.
This came out great. However, I do suggest adding a few tablespoons of lemon juice to the marinade to help tenderize the meat.

No changes 
Yes I will
I marinated the London broil for 48 hrs. No need for steak sauce. it was very good!

I followed the recipe exactly and it was delicious! I've ALWAYS used teriyaki sauce to marinate my London Broil so this was a nice change. Hubby liked it and he generally hates change. Will definitely make it again.

This was a last minute dinner so only marinated it for about 3 hours, then cooked this under the broiler instead of on the grill; 4” away from broiler for 5 to 6 minutes per side. Roasted some potatoes and carrots with rosemary to go along with it and had a delicious meal. It was amazing; definitely on our family menu!
Quite yummy.

Absolutely delicious! The meat was so flavorful and tender. This can be a very tough piece of meat, but marinating it for at least 5 hours made it very tender and delicious. This was a hit with the entire family. And they skipped the steak sauce!
Missing something will not make again
I have been using this marinade for years. It is fantastic! Don't change a thing.
great recipe loved it
1st time making London broil on grill. Easy fast n delicious. Med well 9 mins each side
I never review recipes but this was the best. I only used 1/4 tsp garlic powder instead of the garlic clove. Otherwise followed the recipe exactly. So easy - so delicious.

I used a 2 1/2 pound Chuck roast. I added a second clove of garlic and reduced the pepper to 1/4 teaspoon. I marinated the meat and wrapped it in tin foil and put it in the refrigerator for 6 1/2 hours. I baked in the oven instead of grilling. But I was not sure about temperature and time. I tried 450° and it wasn't done after 42 minutes. I sliced the meat and was able to get it baked through. It was good.
One of my all time favorites! You won't be disappointed.

LOVE this recipe. Our family's favorite meats used to be rib eyes, New York Strips, and lamb chops. This London Broil recipe has ALMOST become our favorite now above all of those! And, I find this cut so much easier to fix for guests. I just double-quadruple the recipe as needed.

Here's the thing, though. SO many reviewers on here are recommending using flank steak. We have done both cuts (flank steak and top round) side by side several times, and our family MUCH prefers the TOP ROUND over the flank cut. 

I follow AmazingRibs.com reverse sear beef and lamb cooking instructions, so I NEVER hot grill/broil any type of beef. I slow roast this cut (and all my beef steaks, roasts, and even lamb) on a rack over a pan at 225 degrees until the inside temp of the meat is about 115 degrees (usually takes about 30-40 minutes). I then sear both sides on a very hot searing burner outside until the outside of the meat has the "proper-looking" sear - usually between 1-2 minutes per side. This makes an outstanding juicy, tender cut of medium-rare meat (be it a thick steak, roast, lamb, etc.). Cooking this recipe, using the labeled "London Broil" meat rather than flank steak, makes a really SCRUMPTIOUS meat!
The London broil turned out well. The steak is very flavorful.
Excellent flavor profile. Added a nice flavor to the meat without being overpowering.
Followed the recipe, came out full of flavor. No one added sauce.

Very tasty. Took some hints from other reviews because my London broil cut of meat was thick. Added 2 tblsp of lemon juice to marinade to help tenderize the meat. Allowed meat to marinate for 48 hours. I used a ziplock bag. 
Broiled my meat about 7 to 8 minute
Es per side and then wrapped in aluminum foil and allowed to set for 10 minutes before slicing. I’ve tried London broil many times and was never happy with results. This was the best. Will make again.
So I made this exactly as instructed. I scored it (which makes all the difference). Then cooked it on the grill for 12-14 minuets. We loved it!
Very good! I let the meat marinate for 24 hours. Finally a London broil that was soft and tasted great.
Forgot to say that I doubled the recipe to make sure there was enough flavor
I made it exactly according to recipe and it was phenomenal. My husband and son also loved it. I will never do a store-bought marinade again.

I've used this recipe for several years now and it's a hit every time. Even both of our sons who have completely opposite likes/dislikes with food flavors both agree this is a winner! (It's a rarity.)
thank you for a fantastic simple recipe.
Only thing I did different was double the marinade. Was really good.
This was super easy to make. Loved the test. Next time I will reduce the amount of salt. Will make again.
Super easy prep where meat was very favorfull. I marinated the meat for 8 hours than made it on my traegger smoker on high heat with cherry wood. Wonderful
Everyone loved it! Will definitely make again.
This was excellent ! I added Worcester sauce and made sure to follow the diamond cuts as the video shows. That way helped cooking!
Pan seared and put in oven because grill was unavailable, and element for broiler broke and was delicious.

The marinade was wonderful, my family really liked that. What they didn't like was the meat I chose. I've only been cooking for a week so I don't know how to pick meat, I did it based on looks. I obviously did it wrong, experience will help I suppose .
Used this as recipe stated. Was outstanding, will definitely use again.

This recipe was amazing. The only thing I suggest is cutting down on the salt because it calls for soy sauce,maybe even leave it out all together. Not sure why it calls for both but that's my opinion. But tasty overall and will recommend with that opinion.

Used almost 4 lbs. London broil. Marinated overnight, flipped london broil in the morning when I made my coffee. Exceptional taste! My hus band took it out of the fridge 10 minuets before putting it on the grill, 8 minuets on each side. Loved the taste!
My family raved about this! Will definitely make it again.
No changes, loved it!

Thanks Jill. Made it yesterday with Josie's additions. 3 tbls of lemon juice to 2 tsp of Worcestershire sauce, 2 tsp of fish sauce, 1 tsp of ground ginger, chili sauce instead of ketchup and 2 tsp of garlic powder. Cut the four pounds into four one pound servings. Wife and I ate one serving. One serving's in the refrigerator. Two in the freezer. Thanks to all you great cooks. From a beginner.

I've made this a half a dozen times and it's always been awesome. We remember the first time we made it and we were amazed what simple ingredients could do, very cool. I've learned not to mess with the ingredient ratios either because it's not the same as the first time.

I made this marinade but doubled it for 2 London broils that were almost 5 lbs. together. I put one in each zip lock bag with half of the marinade (which is really one batch of the recipe). The only things I did differently is that I added lemon juice because I had read it in the reviews instead of meat tenderizer, and added fresh chopped garlic. FANTASTIC!

My first time cooking a London Broil turned out good. I followed the directions but only added more minced garlic. I followed the suggestions of one reviewer to marinate for 48 hours. Since it started raining here, I broiled the beef in the oven on a rack. 8 minutes per side and that was perfect timing. Well done on the ends and medium in the middle. Very flavorful! But was a little tough. I'll make this again.

Since London broil is a tougher cut of meat, I decided to add a little more acid to the recipe by putting 2 teaspoons of lemon juice and 1 teaspoon of worchestershire sauce in with the rest of the marinade ingredients. I also let it marinate for approximately 36 hours. My husband grilled it on high on our gas grill for about 8-9 minutes per side and we let it rest for about 20 minutes. While my son really liked the flavor, he still found it tough. My husband and I loved the flavor so much, the toughness wasn't a huge issue for us. This will probably be my go to recipe for this cut of meat from now on.

This is the best tasting London Broil I've ever ate. I doubled the marinade for a 2-lb cut, scored it, and put it all in a doubled zip locked bag. The meat marinated for 48 hours prior to broiling for 8 minutes on each side (medium rare). Delicious.

It was ok. I added lemon juice to try to help tenderize the meat as suggested by other reviewers. The meat was still tougher than we prefer. The flavor didn't trip our triggers either. Not sure I'll use this again.

I made this with olive oil and omitted the oregano because my husband does not prefer that flavor. I marinated it overnight and grilled it 3-4 minutes per side. My whole family loved it and my 19 year old daughter proclaimed it to be the best beef she has ever eaten. It will certainly be in the regular rotation. I will not make any changes the next time I make it. I also grilled some corn on the cob, placing them on the grill about 5 minutes before the meat, and the timing was perfect.
I wouldn't make again

Super easy and flavorful marinade! It was a nasty rainy day outside, so I seared the meat 5mins on each side on the stovetop in a cast iron skillet then finished in the oven. I let a pat of herbed butter melt overtop it while it rested before slicing. Mmm. Will make again!

Wish I had read the reviewers who educated us on the difference between london broil and flank steak before I made this. Nevertheless, the marinade is good - I put it all in a zip-lock bag for 24 hours, massaging each time I opened the fridge. No doubt the flank steak would have been more tender - I'll be sure to buy that next time.

It worked great even though I didn't plan ahead enough to let it marinade. My husband said it was good and had seconds which is enough for me! I cut the meat into small strips before marinating it since we have a 2 year old. It was kind of hard for him to chew.
Super! I like a spicy smoky flavor, so I added a dash of liquid smoke, one tsp yellow mustard, a couple of Tbsp of red wine vinegar, and increased garlic to 3 cloves.
I made it as written and we loved it. No leftovers. will defi nitely make it again.

So easy. I used the more roast size meat labeled London broil and marinated two days. 4 min each side in the grill pan on medium, then popped in the oven for 15 minutes. Was pink in middle and done perfectly at 140 when removed. Let it rest 5 min. We had it sliced - no steak sauce needed! And second night as French dip. 6 plates out of a $7 piece of meat - wow. Thought was a fluke so did again - lol - just as good! For 2nd night that time sliced thin and simmered for just a minute in saved juices. Oh my yum. Can't wait to fix again!
I cooked this in the broiler on high. About 14 minutes per side makes it medium rare. It was tasty, but a little tough. We'd make it again, but will probably try another recipe before that.
Didn't like this recipe, it was too salty and didn't tenderize the steak.
Loved it. Added a bit of ginger to my marinade to give it a little spice.
This was good, but it was a little too salty. I was already using reduced sodium soy sauce, and if I make this again, I'll skip the extra salt.

Delicious! I omitted the ketchup and added lemon juice as someone else stated. I also added some Montreal steak seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, whorchestire sauce, a little bit of siracha and a splash of red wine vinegar. Stuck it in the sous vide for 6 - 7 he's and it came out super tender! I never thought London broil could be that tender!!! Definitely making this again!
Fantastic
Fantastic
Such a simple recipe that is deliscious!
Very good London Broil recipe. I didn't change a thing, marinated overnight and cooked on grill, high heat, 5 minutes on each side. Definitely a keeper.
Literally the best. I put this marinade on every cut of beef I can get my hands on.
This is a good marinade. I used Worcestershire in place of Soy Sauce by accident, I kinda of lean towards that flavor. All though soy is good also.
Great, easy recipe! And a nice simple grill meal. Tasty. Hubby thought it was a special occasion!
I realm loved this and I used the ingredients but the steak for 1 different flavor and I'm going to use this more
